policies.name: Anti-Racism/Discrimination/Hate Crime
resolvesTo: 1. To ensure equal access to all aspects of University life for all students.
2. To adopt a 'zero tolerance' approach to racism, discrimination and hate crime.
3. To campaign locally and nationally to mobilise students against racism and xenophobia.
4. To use the NHS Hate Crime Report (2011) to prevent racism and hate crime on campus.

policies.name: Nestle (Ethical Policy)
resolvesTo: The Union resolves to have no dealings with, or facilitate the promotion of Nestlé, as a company, including its brands and sub-brands, on the grounds of unfair exploitation of third world countries (based on an independent report by EIRIS which found the company to be “in substantial violation of the International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes”).
policies.archiveNote: Implemented within the Ethical Policy of Sheffield Students' Union as set out in the governing Bye-Laws.

policies.name: Embedding Liberation in Our Union
resolvesTo: 1. To adopt a ‘zero-tolerance’ approach to sexist, racist, LGBT+phobic, and ableist speech and literature in our Union
2. That our Union events, and representative and working committees shall not give a platform to those who silence the voices or discriminate against the identities of oppressed groups
3. To support the campaigns, representation, and self-defining, elected leaders of the Women’s, BME, LGBT+, and disabled committees
4. To provide resources and support to women, LGBT+, BME and disabled students

policies.name: Zero Tolerance to Sexual Harassment
resolvesTo: 1. To adopt a zero-tolerance to sexual harassment policy, and publicise it widely in all Union spaces.
2. To use the NUS definition of sexual harassment.
3. Not to sell, advertise, or endorse any material that condones ‘rape culture’.
policies.archiveNote: This policy now forms part of the complaints and discipline procedures of Sheffield Students' Union. More information on these procedures and the SU's Zero-Tollerance Policy can be found here.

policies.name: Barclays (Ethical Policy)
resolvesTo: 1. The Union resolves to have no dealings with, or facilitate the promotion of Barclays, as a company, including its brands and sub-brands, on the grounds of undertaking actions harmful to the environment. Barclays own 97% of Third Energy - the company with a licence to frack in North Yorkshire. Sheffield is likely to be fracked if it isn't opposed as a technology now. Peer-reviewed research highlights a number of severely debilitating health effects of fracking on local communities, and its emissions are likely to make the UK's commitments to tackle global warming impossible. Globally, Barclays have £15.6 billion in fossil fuel assets including in the Dakota Access Pipeline.

policies.name: Food for Future
resolvesTo: The SU will explicitly label Kosher, Halal, vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free and allergen friendly foods. Vegetarian options to be advertised before meat options on menus.
Have allergen friendly options for all of the top allergens, including vegetarian and vegan options.
Ensure the food offering across campus caters to International students.
To not sell red meat except pork and ensure ⅔ of options in all outlets are vegetarian and where feasible ⅓ of these are vegan.
Vegetarian food offered as standard for events catering, lobbying the university to do the same.
Oat milk will be offered as standard. Customers can request dairy milk. This will be monitored and a charge for dairy milk will be added if emissions do not drop.
Food emissions should be tracked by the SU, written on menus and publicised to students. Clear annual reduction goals will be set.
Prioritise the sale of affordable food by maintaining affordable meal deals, introducing more affordable hot food and guaranteeing an affordable option for all dietary needs at every outlet.
When replacing outlets, introduce a fully vegetarian/vegan outlet with international food offerings.
Host regular events, with a month that promotes plant based and sustainable diets.

policies.name: Standing with Jewish Students
resolvesTo: 1. To adopt the IHRA definition of antisemitism in full and to refer to it when complaints of antisemitism are made to the Students' Union.
2. To lobby the university to also adopt the IHRA definition in full.

policies.name: End Israeli Occupation
resolvesTo: 1. Ensure that relevant groups such as our Palestine Society are able to commemorate Palestine Solidarity Day.
2. To work with such relevant groups to lobby our university to divest itself from and terminate any contracts with companies that are complicit in the occupation of the Palestinian territories.

3. To support our student groups to raise awareness of the global Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement against the Israeli government until it ends the occupation and complies with international law.

policies.name: Drugs Harm Reduction
resolvesTo: 1. To fully comply with the law regarding controlled drugs and the conditions of our licensed premises
2. To prioritise student welfare in our approach to drugs, emphasising education and access to support services
3. To lobby and educate local government to move away from zero tolerance and towards harm reduction
4. To oppose the harsh criminalisation of personal drug use, educate members on the harms caused by drug prohibition, and argue for a national change in legislation
5. To be transparent and open about our procedures around drugs

policies.name: Cops Off Campus
resolvesTo: Maintain the SUC Voting Record as a publicly available and easily accessible resource.
Display individual officer and councillor voting history underneath their profile on the SU website (updated after each Council).
Create a dedicated space on the SU website for candidates to expand on their manifestoes and experience, with voting records clearly displayed (if applicable).

policies.name: Make Abstentions Make Sense Again
resolvesTo: Amend the bye-laws to add the following:
5.1 Each member shall have one vote
5.1.1 They shall have the option to vote yes, no or abstain
5.1.2 For the avoidance of doubt, abstentions shall count towards quoracy
5.1.3 A simple majority of abstentions shall trigger a re-vote, a repeated majority of abstentions brings the item back for discussion in a future Council.

policies.name: A Better Deal For Our Future
resolvesTo: 1. Voting on one of these two manifestos (1) and (2) to be the one that we use in national negotiations and campaigning for a better deal for students.

2. For the remit of the Education Officer and President to be written in such a way that they are contractually obligated to campaign for better deals on tuition fees, maintenance loans/grants, and financing systems for Higher Education.
Short/Medium/Long term:
Short: Being able to share our manifesto with other student unions, NUS, and MPs who will be able to back it and give us a way to have conversations around these changes.
Medium: Creating a campaign, petition, and working group to ensure that we can get enough student backing for the campaign.
Long: To be in conversations with MPs and members of the PM's Cabinet for the improvement of the student support system in the UK.
